segments.text: Now, I'm sure that you've seen a lot of movies recently about Vietnam.
How do you feel they portray the experience?
Movies like The Deer Hunter and Apocalypse Now and Platoon and Full Metal Jacket, those types of movies, how do they portray what you saw and how do you think that's experienced?
Well, let's see.
About ten years ago is when I first saw The Deer Hunter and Apocalypse Now.
I remember going to Apocalypse Now with my son Roland one night when I was very tired, and I remember sleeping through part of it, so I don't know that I really ever understood it.
But it seemed to me that it was probably, there was a lot more imagery in the movie than truth.
It seemed to me that the movie was about a very unusual individual and the ways that he went about dealing with the problem.
and I don't think I really know very much about that part of it.
The Deer Hunter, I remember seeing it, and it was a very gripping movie.
I had been told about it by another friend of mine who was also a doctor in Vietnam, and he described how it made him feel, and then when I went to the movie, it made me feel exactly the same way.
And I think the gripping thing about it was was how
Poorly, the American soldier was treated when he got back home after he was there doing the best job he possibly could.
His country really treated him almost like an outlaw or something.
They treated him inferiorly, I believe.
They didn't treat him like returning heroes or returning patriots at all.

And I think many of the guys like were kind of portrayed in the movie in terms of drinking and other ways of just kind of hiding their disbelief that their country had sort of disowned them for going over there and doing their job.
I remember several scenes I think in the Deer Slayer that were very gripping where they were playing Russian roulette.
And I think that person's mind had already sort of degenerated to the point where he really didn't care whether he came back home or not.
He was going to make a lot of money if he possibly could doing whatever he was doing there, and it may not have been legal.
But, you know, he really didn't have any desire to come back home, even though his friends were looking for him.
Did you ever see any people like that where you were getting on?
No, I don't think so.
I never...
I never was around the bigger cities where people could stay for a long period of time.
Like in July, I mean, sorry, in Saigon, there were many civilians who went to Saigon and just worked for companies in building trades and that sort of thing.
They would stay there for years and I think many of them maybe began to feel like this and they didn't have any desire to come back home at all.
Most of the soldiers I saw were only there for a year, and then they rotated back, and I don't think that they commonly felt quite as badly.
Most movies seem to be over-portrayed in order to make a point on certain feelings and that sort of thing, and I think Deer Slayer did that.
Platoon, I think, was one of the most accurately filmed movies up to its time, and I think it did very accurately portray the way

particularly infantry men, looked at the war, how they looked at the Vietnamese, how they looked at each other, how they many times hated their superior sergeant or captain or major or whoever who was making them do things that many times didn't seem logical or human, humane even.
It's Caitlin, what?
Patient Ken Fabisi.
Oh, okay.
Now, while you were over there, did you notice any of the drug problems, or do you think those came about later on, and why do you think that came about?
Well, I have an opinion on it.
While I was there, I didn't see very many drug problems.

We occasionally would catch a guy smoking marijuana, which was illegal, and he would be given, usually in Article 15, which was either a fine or some detention or some extra work or something like that.
The Vietnamese had it though all the time and they were smoking it around on our posts where they were.
And I remember numerous times smelling it because it had a very stinky odor.
But I never actually saw any marijuana being sold or passed around.
Once or twice we had some hoopla going on in a camp when some sergeant would think some of his guys were smoking it and we would
have a sneak inspection of their barracks and all that sort of thing out of the tents.
And I don't recall where we ever found anything that was significant nature.
The people that I work with, though, were very high caliber people and tended to have plenty to do and weren't really bored because we were running a medical facility.
They were either like nurses, corpsman,
x-ray technicians, medical technicians, or assistants to the dentist, or they were cooking for the unit or something.
They were never really sitting around with nothing to do.
We all had jobs to do.
So I don't think I saw, saw it more than twice in the six months I was at this facility.
It was never a problem anywhere I was at during the whole year I was there because I think everybody was busy.
And they wanted to be under control of their own mental facilities.
And I think a druggie would have been gotten rid of by his own mate simply because they couldn't trust him anymore.
And most guys didn't want somebody around they couldn't trust because it was dangerous.
And the war was still actively going on in 68, 69.
And I think shortly after that, when they were trying to turn the program over to the Vietnamese,
And the American soldier didn't have very much to do.
There wasn't very much activity going on.
That's when the drugs became more of a problem.
And that was a 69, 70, 71 problem.
Okay.

Now, you know, as a mature adult, you've been around, and that's kind of realized what, you know, do you now think that you know a lot more about why you went to Vietnam, why things were done the way they were, things like that?
Are you still just kind of?
I'm still kind of in limbo about all that.
I don't really know any more about it than I did then, even though I've made some attempts to study it.
I'm not sure anybody knows why we were in Vietnam.
From a medical standpoint, I was there doing a job taking care of the fighting soldier and I did a good job at that.
I liked what I did and I felt good about taking care of the fighting men.
I saw a lot of activity, both
from the war standpoint and from the medical standpoint.
And we had extremely good medical facilities.
Our soldiers had as good a medical care as there was in the world at the time.
And I still don't have any idea really why we were there because it didn't make sense to me while I was there and it doesn't make sense to me right now either.
I just don't think we had a real purpose when we went there.
And I don't know what
how the decision was made to get us started there to start with, but I think it was kind of ill-founded.
You know, today looking back, do you feel that your experience in Vietnam changed you in any way?
Well, probably so.
I think my experience in Vietnam made me appreciate the United States for what it is a lot more.
I've certainly been much more patriotic since I came back.
I was patriotic when I left, but I feel
much more strongly that the United States is still the best country in the world and the best country that the world has ever had, present on its face actually.
I still believe strongly that the American people are the best group of people anywhere and that they can always be counted upon to do their job when they're asked to under the right circumstances.
So I really think it changed me for the good because it helped me
mature earlier and quicker I think in many ways.

I learned an awful lot there from a medical surgical standpoint and I also had a fair amount of administrative experience there so it really helped me be prepared I think to do jobs that I had to do as a hospital chief of surgery or chief of staff or some of the jobs that we had to do as doctors in a civilian hospital.
And I think it was a very positive experience for me the year that I spent there, actually.
